PR_Association_for_Indias_Development_St.Purpose:: Purpose: To support Indigenous communities from 200 villages across four districts of West Bengal to ensure that forest resources are sustainably used, conserved, and regenerated. AID promotes sustainable, equitable, and just development. It supports grassroots organisations in India working on education, livelihoods, natural resources, agriculture, health, gender, and social justice.    7.
PR_Association_for_Indias_Development_St.Progress Against Objectives: Progress Against Objectives Under each expected project objective, briefly explain your progress in reaching the objective and its results, and discuss any changes you propose to the project goals or objectives with the PO.  7.1.a. Objective 1 Use the Forest Rights Act to claim legal rights for individuals and communities and strengthen grassroots democratic institutions in 200 villages across 4 districts of northern West Bengal.   7.1.b. Objective 1: Principal accomplishments Very good ground mobilis ation despite the pandemic. The following meetings at various levels were organised. 20 community level meetings were organised with 40 participants on an average. Any adult in the village can attend this type of open meeting. In some places women participation is less as they go to work in others homes for domestic help or they go to forest for foraging. Increasing livelihood options in the village will help womens increase participation. The purpose of these meetings was to provide basic orientation on the FRA and talk about the provisions under FRA to start new Gram Sabhas. 1 district level meeting was organised where Gram Sabha members from 30 villages spread across 3 districts had participated. Basically, the district meeting was organised to raise awa reness around FRA so that representatives would go back to their respective villages and work with other villagers in order to strengthen their Gram Sabhas. Sometimes people don't realise that they got less land while getting the Patta. Those who have rece ived less land under IFR are going back to the district officials. Those villages that have not been converted to revenue villages have started the process as a result of this meeting. 3 alliance building meetings with like -minded organisations were organi sed in Nagpur, Kolkata and in Purulia. Different groups related to forest issues from different districts have participated in the meetings so that the FRA is implemented better across the state. Village level leadership committees were formed in 7 villages to drive the community processes through Gram Sabhas. Capacity building workshop on GPS & satellite mapping is going on for CFR mapping in the operational forest villages with the Gram Sabha representatives so that they can authenticate their cust omary forest boundary and claim CFR with the map. Besides, the regular meetings, interactions with the forest and district administration are being continued because the implementation of FRA has to be recognized by the government. FRA guidelines are not being followed. The process is not done correctly by the government hence people have to repeatedly go for the correction of land records, ensure their representation in the Sub Divisional Level Committee (SDLC) and bringing issues back in the village.     7.1.c. Objective 1: Shortfalls The starting of developing the audio-visual materials have been delayed due to Covid pandemic.     7.2.a. Objective 2 To create livelihood opportunities for the communities living in and around the forest  to  build their resilience and encourage conservation of forests and the surrounding landscape.   7.2.b. Objective 2: Principal accomplishments The outcomes of the livelihood activities have surpassed our own expectations. People were mobilised in 25 villages to form clusters for community level farming. Around 680 families involved in farming have reaped a harvest in jute, mustard and vegetables.   300 families were involved in Jute farming and each family had made an average additional income of Rs.27,000  350 families were involved in mustard farming and each family had made an additional income of around Rs.10,000 to Rs.12,000. The marketing of mustard oil is in the process. People in these clusters have brought 330 acres of land under mustard cultivation.  35 families in Nimati village were involved in vegetable farming and each made an additional income of Rs.600 All of these are additional income for the families because earlier they used to grow rice and then the land remained unused for the rest of the year. Rice is mainly grown for sustenance. Most of the villagers in the operational area are daily wage earners. On an average they earn around Rs.300 per day as labourers. Usually they get 4 months of work in a year which earns around Rs.36,000 annually per family. The clusters involved in farming have been able to make some additional income on top of their annual income from labour work  because of this livelihood initiative.   There have been some farmers who grow jute for which they  take a loan of Rs.400 for a bigha (0.33 acre) from the money lender. And farmers who were involved in commercial mustard farming used to take a loan of Rs.5000 to 600 per  bigha (0.33 acre)  for the initial input costs. This year the situation has changed or got better in a way because the cluster got the seed and other input support for farming and also had a good income from the harvest.  Apart from the farming initiatives, 2 nurseries have been raised in different villages with a total of 80,000 saplings of local indigenous varieties from the forest. The plantation will happen in monsoon season on all the degraded lands along the customary boundaries of the forest villages.  Formal meetings with all the Gram Sabhas in 25 villages happened and resolutions were passed in order to initiate the farming and plantation work in the forest villages. Several follow up meetings with the Gram Sabha and the clusters had been carried out to start the newly adopted livelihood initiative. Besides, some workshops on the technical aspect of organic farming were also organised in 25 villages with the farmers involved in clusters.     7.2.c. Objective 2: Shortfalls We are a bit late in terms of plantation effort because the seed collection was delayed  due to the Covid induced lockdown. Plantation is a time sensitive work. We missed the first plantation time because of the delayed seed collection and we had to wait for the next plantation time. On top of that the first batch of saplings got destroyed by the elephants for which we had to change the location of one of the nurseries.      7.3.a. Objective 3 To develop a new rung of leadership from the youth (12 to 18 years) through an education that is rooted in their socio-cultural-ecological context and empowers them to develop self-reliance and live in their culture with dignity.   7.3.b. Objective 3: Principal accomplishments We could not organise any formal workshops in the initial months of the project due to Covid pandemic. However,  several rounds of discussion have been done with the adolescents and youth (aged between 12 to 18 years old) both including men and women in different villages. Based on those interactions we are now developing the learning modules which will be completed by April, 2022.  Due to the enthusiasm from the community we increased the learning centre from six to seven. Selection of teachers through an interview process from the community has been done. We are in the process of buying one desktop for each centre. We observed the FRA day on December 18th in which people from different villages participated, and community members of different tribes presented their unique cultural performances.   7.3.c. Objective 3: Shortfalls We could not organise any formal workshops on planned time for developing the learning modules due to the Covid pandemic. However, our experts (resource persons) have visited all the targeted villages several times in order to interact with the women and youth groups in the process of dev eloping basic learning modules.  No school level competitions could be done because schools were closed due to the Covid-19 induced restrictions.      8.
PR_Association_for_Indias_Development_St.What has your team learned during the im: What has your team learned during the implementation and evaluation of your project? 1. In the process of nursery development, we have learned that forest villagers want indigenous varieties that grow naturally in the forest for their nurseries unlike timber that is always promoted for plantation. The forest villagers believe that plantations of more indigenous variety can restore the degraded forest patches and eventually reduce the human-animal conflict.  2. We have found that the youth group in the villages are very enthusiastic about computer education.  3. We also learned that cluster farming can have a huge impact on the income of the families.     9.
PR_Association_for_Indias_Development_St.How will your team use this information: How will your team use this information to change the way you work? 1. We are raising only indigenous varieties in our nurseries. There is no plan for timber plantation. 2. We have incorporated computer learning in all 7 centers. All centers will start with one desktop each this year. 3. The huge production of mustard and jute has made us think of exploring the scope of value addition and marketing initiatives. We have already started talking to the clusters on the marketing efforts.   10.
PR_Association_for_Indias_Development_St.How will you share what you have learned: How will you share what you have learned inside and outside your organisation? We will discuss the processes and outcomes with our other partners. The outcomes have really given us a lot of enthusiasm and have driven us to think that we may try to implement some of the successful examples in other areas with different partners.      11. PR_A_Dignity_Alliance_International_Supp.Purpose:: Purpose: To help strengthen the Migrant Resilient Collaborative (MRC) in India, which aims to protect migrant workers by regulating placements and work conditions and providing them with full access to safety nets and entitlements. Approximately 240,000 migrant workers will be directly impacted as an initial step. The MRC is a grassroots-led collaborative of not-for-profit, philanthropic, and private sector actors focused on ensuring safety, security, and mobility for vulnerable migrant families across India. Objective 1 Objective Strengthening social security delivery system and increasing access to benefits and entitlements    7.1.b. Objective 1 Progress. What progress has been made toward the above grant objective(s) over the last grant period?  Please focus your response on progress against desired outcomes or changes that occurred because of the activities; do not only describe what activities occurred or products of these efforts (i.e., Training manuals; policy briefs, etc).  The Oak Project: As part of our ongoing efforts to create a social registry for migrant workers, our Jan Saathis registered 1,30,859 migrant workers across sources and destinations on the Jan Saathi mobile application during the project period, out of which 70906 women have been registered on the portal. These workers were also provided with pre-departure and post-arrival training sessions. In these sessions, the workers are informed about their rights and the mechanisms in place to safeguard them. The workers are also informed about the various entitlements that they can access at the destination and source they are currently present.   Social status of families registered in West Bengal   The team has been successful in facilitating 78,153 scheme applications for various households. Out of these, till May 2022, 70,201 applications have converted to benefits of which 36,154 are for women-led households. The application-to-benefit conversion ratio is (~89%) which is similar to what was envisaged at the start of the program.  Overall MRC Progress: In the MRC program, running across 13 states, we have currently reached out to 28,22,497 households since October 2020, they have been registered with the Migrants Resilience Collaborative. Aligned with our strategy to register women as primary respondents for the households, 40% of households have a woman as the primary respondent in May 2022. Our Jan Saathis uses the mobile application to check eligible schemes for registered migrant workers and facilitate applications for such schemes. The Jan Saathis also tracks the delivery of benefits for each application they help submit. The major schemes that we focused on in West Bengal were Lakshmi Bhandar, Krishak Bandhu, old age pension, widow pension, disability pension, Bina Mulya Samajik Suraksha Yojana, BOCW, PMSBY, E-shram, BMSSY and Swasthya Sathi.  Our team was able to facilitate and implement all the above-mentioned activities smoothly through the constant support of the district labor officials.   Oak Progress Report.    3 Till May 22, 26.6 lakh scheme applications were facilitated and 22.20 lakh benefits were received in the MRC program, working across 13 states The focus in many states was in ensuring the filing of applications for the community instead of only registering them. In May 2022, the major schemes under which applications were filed include EShram, PMSY , Ayushman Bharat, BoCW cards, PM Kisan Saman Nidhi, PM Awas Yojana, MGNREGA and work related to ration.      7.1.c. Objective 1 Challenges and obstacles. We expect that the work toward grant objectives may not occur as originally planned due to internal and external factors.  Please share a candid assessment of areas of challenge and learning and whether any adjustments were made. 1. Due to the second wave of Covid19, our operations were halted from April 21- June 21. 2. Political interference at the local level affects operation. Despite securing support from Gram Pradhan, the team often faces resistance from other members of the same political party. 3. The MRC during the initial days did not receive support from the community. They believed that we had come from NRC and harassed our team members.   4. Government does not accept offline application forms. The only medium to submit the applications is through Duare Sarkar camps. Currently, there are no mechanisms for submitting the applications for state-specific schemes online, so the team has to wait for duare Sarkar camps to happen in order to submit the application form. This makes availing the entitlement lengthy.    7.2.a. Objective 2 Objective Enabling responsible recruitment    7.2.b. Objective 2 Progress. The Oak Project: In West Bengal, the team has been getting access to new construction sites under Mission BOCW. Mission BOCW has been largely successful and we have further streamlined implementation support on sites to ensure workers can access social security support, keeping the effect of on-site operations to a minimum. The team in Kolkata engages in 2 sites that come under and till now, 1087 applications have been submitted for 355 unique workers and 751 benefits were delivered for 348 unique workers at construction sites. Overall MRC Progress: In the last year, the team has focused on Mission BOCW which is a coordinated effort with the government, private sector, and civil society to help migrant construction workers and their familys tide over the crisis. Through this campaign, we aim to register one million construction workers by December'22 in 100 cities and districts of 12 states of India.  Oak Progress Report.    4 The targeted outcome this year was to get labor responsibly recruited to Industries but as we proceeded, we understood that to responsibly recruit labor we need to first initiate partnerships with the industry to gain access to sites. Hence, we started to focus on Mission BOCW as a stepping stone towards the larger goal of responsible recruitment which will be an eventual outcome of the same.  We are currently engaging with 11 industry partners (employers) across the textile and construction sectors. These include names Such as BCI, CREDAI, BCI, HDFC, Godrej and Tata Realty. In Partnership with HDFC capital, we are in the process of launching an initiative aimed at recognizing and rewarding the industrys best practices, which in turn will ensure proactive engagement of real estate companies in providing social security for the construction workers compliance at the sites under HDFC capital. An LOI has been signed with the CREDAI National (The prime industry body of construction developers), through which they will help with onboarding developers onto the Mission BOCW-where social security entitlements will be facilitated on-site at all MRC destination cities.      7.2.c. Objective 2 Challenges and obstacles. We expect that the work toward grant objectives may not occur as originally planned due to internal and external factors.  Please share a candid assessment of areas of challenge and learning and whether any adjustments were made. 1. Gaining access to sites has been a major challenge.  2. Even after receiving permission for the sites, the onsite managers create hindrance in registering the workers for BOCW. 3. Lack of proper documents (Aadhaar card, bank details etc.)  with the workers at construction sites limits our ability to facilitate social security entitlements. 4. Besides, the presence of promoters of real estate companies/ site managers often hinders interaction of Jan Saathis with the workers and the ability of the workers to share their problems freely. 5. The onsite managers expect that the scheme's benefits should be given immediately to the laborers, which is not possible as the delivery is determined by the processes at the Labor and other relevant departments. 6. BOCW and many major schemes are not applicable for inter-state migrant workers in West Bengal. A number of workers in Kolkata, especially in the construction sector, are inter-state migrants which could not be benefited due to the limitations.     7.3.a. The team has received 4 cases of accidents at the workplace, 1 case of minimum wages, 1 case of forced labour, 91 cases of non-payment of wages. The helpline has received calls from over 425 districts across the country. We have hired lawyers who are helping our team and stakeholders in implementing and imbibe SOPs, enabling and capacitating the system towards transformation- Exposure to labour departments, community volunteer building relationships and sensitization of field and central teams. We have a dedicated lawyer in each state.        7.3.c. Objective 3 Challenges and obstacles. Objectives  Oak Progress Report.    2  Objective: Resilience to climate change among tribal communities is increased through identification of their challenges, their empowerment and dissemination of knowledge gained with relevant actors. A follow up project to scale up the interventions will be designed based on the lessons from this pilot.   7.b. Progress.  What progress has been made toward the above grant objective(s) over the last grant period?  Please focus your response on progress against desired outcomes or changes that occurred because of the activities; do not only describe what activities occurred or products of these efforts (i.e., Training manuals; policy briefs, etc).  In Output 1, significant progress has been achieved. Various studies, including an Ethnographic Survey of 800 households, PVCA, and Action research, have completed the needs assessment. Findings indicate that nearly 50 % of tribal households lack tribal identity cards, hindering their access to government policies. The project aided 300 beneficiaries in obtaining caste certificates and supported 144 beneficiaries in accessing government schemes. PVCA using PRA tools was accomplished in 8 villages, offering insights into resources, hazard exposure, vulnerability, and coping capacity. The Action research guided the project timeline and methods, including multi-hazard mapping, website creation, and PVCA framework. Land Use and Land Cover mapping using Remote Sensing and GIS analysis and communication of weather forecasts and crop advisories through Information Hubs are in progress to assist the farmers. Knowledge was shared via the new project website (https://soundofsilencesundarban.com/). Output 2 involves forming 69 WSHGs and 16 Youths' Groups, involving 800 households and 215 young individuals. Capacity training was completed in all 8 villages for 380 participants. Initiatives include Information Hubs for education, employment, and NRM-based vocations. Ongoing efforts ensure weather forecasts and hazard warnings in Bengali. Output 3 showcases accomplishments. LRRM held health camps for 71 women in Kultali, with more planned by DRCSC in other areas. Both organizations have also appealed to the respective Block Development Offices (BDOs) for organizing vaccination drives. Football equipment was distributed to 8 youths groups, along with plans for exercise and training under sought trainers.   7.c. Challenges and obstacles.  We expect that the work toward grant objectives may not occur as originally planned due to internal and external factors.  Please share a candid assessment of areas of challenge and learning and whether any adjustments were made. Some challenges occurred where adjustments had to be made and the following learnings have been obtained:  Setting up field offices in the blocks of Kakdwip, Sandeshkhali I and Kultali, where none existed, was an ordeal owing to the lack of availability of suitable office spaces with basic amenities such as washrooms, drinking water and electricity.  Delays in obtaining the necessary permission from local government offices for the implementation of project activities in the selected villages and blocks. PR_SEWA_Bharat_AssisWomenWorkeInTheUnorg.Purpose:: Purpose: To support women in the unorganised workforce in Jharkhand and West Bengal, India to secure their identity as workers, as well as their rights to full employment, decent wages, and safe and dignified working conditions. PR_SEWA_Bharat_AssisWomenWorkeInTheUnorg.Progress Against Objectives: Progress Against Objectives Under each expected project objective, briefly explain your progress in reaching the objective and its results, and discuss any changes you propose to the project goals or objectives with the PO.  7.1.a. Objective 1 To empower communities through access to information and entitlements with the help of the SEWA Shakti Kendras [SEWA empowerment centres] in Jharkhand and West Bengal   7.1.b. Objective 1: Principal accomplishments The experience of SEWA and similar organizations demonstrate that workers in the informal economy, especially women, benefit from organising themselves to identify their status as workers and demand better working conditions and fair wages. Organizing enables an otherwise scattered labour force to negotiate with employers and decision-makers from the government. It is to this end that SEWA works with women in the informal economy to improve women and girls agency and visibility, autonomy and secure their socio-economic rights. The programme across two states of Jharkhand and West Bengal works to address the systematic issues affecting women and girls and to advance the rights of these women as informal women workers under the gamut of the unorganised sector. Throughout the past fifteen months, the perils of COVID-19 continued to present multiple challenges to our members, through the second lockdown imposed in the months of April-May 2021, followed by the third wave of COVID inflicted field restrictions in January-February 2022. For West Bengal, this situation was also politically charged in the state with the Legislative Assembly election throughout March and April 2021, which led to a fairly slow start to programme activities as per the Workplan. In Bengal, the situation was aggravated by another challenge: the floods in Malda. Almost 15000 community members in Malda faced flooding during the rainy season. Meanwhile, in Jharkhand, the situation was aggravated due to a lack of proper channels of communication, which got lost due to the sufficient infrastructure available for our members. Throughout the year, the grassroots leaders and organisers in both states have worked dedicatedly towards increasing engagements resulting in outreach: Trade West Bengal Jharkhand Beedi workers 21000   Domestic workers 4000 1600 Agriculture   3907 Construction   1400 Others   587 Taking the membership base across both states to 32494, increasing the membership by 20% in year 1 of the current grant.  Through the experience of engaging with informal women workers, grassroots leadership has emerged at the CORE for any programme development or strengthening of the SEWA movement for SEWA Bharat.   Aagewans (SEWA grassroots women leaders) are the elected leaders in the SEWA movement. They are the face of SEWA. The Program aims to increase the bargaining power of these grassroots leaders by developing their capacities to provide leadership in their communities and understand issues surrounding the women in the informal economy be it in trade, occupation, rights and access. Due to their local presence, Agewans are often approached by SEWA members and the larger community to help them register for government schemes or benefits, as well as to negotiate wages and issues with employers. Aagewans play a vital role in the SEWA movement as they are the bridge between the Government, contractors of work and all the women working in the informal economy to ensure the last-mile delivery of services and support to them. Therefore,  facilitating their capacity building and knowledge enhancement around SEWA s work is our foremost priority.  The team in West Bengal focused the interventions on activating aagevans towards an action-oriented approach and emphasised the need to reach out to more women workers. Whilst in Jharkhand, which is relatively a newer intervention area, the focus is to further strengthen the collectivisation process led by the aagevans so that they can lead the trade-specific advocacy and government liaisoning.   Capacity Building of Agewans through Agewan Vikas Training Throughout the year from March 2021 onwards, the Agewan received various training and knowledge building sessions. In Jharkhand, two batches covering  40 Agewan completed their Agewan Vikas Program training course which focused on the following modules (1) SEWA Ideology (2) Importance of Union & Trade organising (3) Identifying issues and taking community issues (4) Trade committee.  Across West Bengal, the training(s) was conducted to equip 106 agewans with the knowledge and skills required to become efficient leaders at the community level.  For the Bengal team, post the training the agewans from every block prepared a three-month plan in which they included linkages with government schemes like Swasthya Sathi, Ration Adhaar link, preparing a rate chart for domestic workers etc. This made the process of evaluating the growth of aagevans across the year more thorough.  Various inputs given to the aagevans throughout the year, in the form of training(s), sessions or discussions have led to not only increased awareness of aagevans among the community members but resulted in several actions being taken by aagevans that manifested their leadership qualities.  Topics Participation - West Bengal Topics Participation - Jharkhand Awareness on Skill development and Alternative livelihood 108; KVIC Agewan Vikas Program Module training  40 Aagewan  Health Awareness session 16; SEWA resource person Health Master Trainer in Hazaribagh  20 Master trainers (The Agewans) Aagewan Vikash 106; SEWA resource person Trade Committee Understanding and E-Shram Portal registration process session  25 Agewan & 12 SEWA Jharkhand Staff Wage code & Social Security code 60; Joint labour commissioner V .V Giri Trainings  12 SEWA Jharkhand staff  Panchayat system 45; SEWA resource person Economic & Social Security (ITUC-TURIN) 1 SEWA Jharkhand staff National Rural Livelihood Guarantee Act 45; SEWA resource person       PWDV A, 2005 40 Domestic workers; protection officer, Murshidabad 60 Beedi workers: District Judge, DLSA     Today, they have a higher degree of confidence as a result of their training, and their participation has increased in community and trade activities. They are also gradually leading the SEWA meetings held in their localities, moderating the sessions to the best of their ability. They also assist in the development of the strategy for monthly community and trade events in their respective locations. The agewans are facilitating social security linkages in collaboration with the SEWA Shakti Kendra linkages such as E-Shram portal registration, conducting Mahila Arogya Meetings and linking communities with public health services. In West Bengal,  through the above -mentioned training in Berhampore, 4 agewans have taken up the responsibility to conduct unit meetin gs (a unit is a cluster of 20 -30 local women coming together for a common purpose)  and mobilize the domestic workers who are coming from the outskirts of the city to fix their rates. Shampa ben and Deepali ben, two agewans (domestic workers) got a chance to take part in the SEWA National level domestic workers workshop in November 2021 where they highlighted their issues on the National platform. This knowledge helps them to mobilize others and talk about their demands with their employers. The domestic wo rkers in Bengal were able to visit the labour department to enrol themselves under Samajik Suraksha Yojana (a social security scheme of the W Bengal government). This was important as otherwise they would not have any Social Security as the state does not recognise the Domestic Workers as workers as yet. The Labour Commissioner agreed and committed to helping them with the enrollment. In Jharkhand, the Agewans are representing their trade memorandum to MPs and participating in the process of memorandum su bmission. In the years 2021 and 2022, they submitted the advocacy points regarding ILO Convention 189 (Provisioned work rights of domestic workers: Decent wage, favourable workplace, fixed work hours, 4 weekly holidays in a month, no discrimination at the workplace, wage on time)   for developing more inclusive policies for domestic workers in the country under the guidance of the National Domestic Workers platform. This has garnered the recognition of agewans among key community leaders such as the Municipa l Councillor. Through the social security sessions, the Agewans now understand the importance of registration of members under the Labour Board according to their trade and have been continuously engaging with them to ensure all their area members are gett ing registered under the BoCW Board, Unorganised Workers Board and the E-Shram Portal. Digital Recognition: Many Agewan represented themselves on many digital platforms in the year 2021 by video documentation and online session participation, discussing th eir work and their journey as Agewan in their neighbourhood as well as at their workplace, and highlighting the conversation on worker rights.   Aagevan led meetings at the community level, SEWA Bharat, in West Bengal, has been organising women through uni t meetings and giving them a platform where they can come together and discuss their community -specific issues and address them jointly. A total of 473 meetings were conducted by 24 agewans across Murshidabad and Malda reaching up to more than 10000 members. The various topics on which meetings were conducted included Government schemes like SSY , Lakhir Bhandar, Duare Sarkar, E-shram card and community level issues including sanitation, safety etc. Through these meetings, it is ensured that women from the community have access to information on schemes and services which otherwise they would not be aware of and therefore would not be able to avail of the benefits covered under the schemes. Being members of the marginalised group, women are often exploited in the name of scheme linkages and become victims of fraud. Through these meetings, they are well informed about the schemes which prevent them from falling into any trap. Through the meetings community members have collectively taken up action to protest against low wages and held   meetings with Mahajans to put forward their demands, To ensure good health and hygiene within the community signature campaign was held at Suti (block in Raghunathganj) and a letter was submitted to panchayat in demand of improving drainage to which the panchayat responded and acted upon. These meetings also enable women to come out of their confined zones and share their concerns in the meeting. This gives them more courage and confidence to interact and express their views. In Jharkhand, the agewans have started conducting meetings in the community on what they learn from SEWA and that which need to be reached out to the members. as they are leading meetings in the new areas and this is helping SEWA to expand its work and membership in Jharkhand.  A total of 25 such women are regularly undertaking the responsibilities of an Aagevan forward.   Awareness programmes conducted by Agewans: Various awareness sessions and meetings were held on topics like government health structure, balan ced diet, vaccination, awareness regarding COVID -19 safety protocols, and the importance of sanitation and hygiene in everyday life across Malda and Murshidabad. A total of  10 awareness programmes were conducted by agewans in their community, reaching up to more than 500 members across Malda and Murshidabad. The programmes were used as a platform to address the myths and misconceptions related to health practices, and vaccination at the ground level which makes them vulnerable to the diseases but due to the intervention of the agewans through the meetings and awareness sessions, our members have become sensitised and are taking steps to break the myths and misconceptions. Our agewans have successfully referred 6000 members for the first dose of vaccination and 4000 for the second dose of vaccination. In addition to the ongoing concern about health, many sessions and programmes were also centred around the loss of work and the importance of restoring livelihoods. 10 agewans and 3 youth group members mobilized village members in Pathanpara, Lalgola (Block in Murshidabad) and collectively demanded an increase in wages for beedi rolling at the Block level office. The agewans were joined by the other community members and other trade unions such as CITU (Centre of Indian Trade Unions). In response to their demand wages increased from Rs 155 to Rs 165, for every 1000 bidis. This was also supported by a larger intervention to protect the livelihood of the marginalised, SEWA Bharat facilitated linkage with MGNREGA; a total of 150 members received work through this. In Jharkhand, the result of a public meeting conducted by the domestic workers in Ranchi, wherein they demanded work in Urban and to start Urban MGNREGA in the city as well, was conducted under the National Domestic Workers platform. Members started getting themselves registered under Urban MGNREGA, by the year-end of 2022, Agewan  (Sunita Orain) from Pandra Ranchi reported that along with her more than 10 members have received 90 days of Job under Ranchi Municipal Corporation for sweeping work in Vendor Market.  My Fair Home Campaign by Domestic workers  Berhampore, Murshidabad Increasing fear of transmission among common people and lockdown rules led to the loss of livelihood among domestic workers as most of the employers were not ready to allow domestic workers at their homes and as a result, they were deprived of wages, continued to be a persistent problem even during the second-wave of COVID -19 pandemic. SEWA Bengal initiated the  My Fair Home Campaign in Berhampore, Murshidabad to promote fair wages and get domestic workers back to work through negotiation with the employers. Through the campaign, 5 domestic workers who lost their jobs due to the pandemic got back their jobs. Rina Mondal is one of the Domestic workers who took part in the campaign, After the lockdown was imposed due to the emerging second wave of the pandemic she was asked by her employer to not come to work nor was she being paid a minimum wage to support her family duri ng the distressing time. Through the campaign 3 agewans and 2 domestic workers and organisers from SEWA West Bengal collectively approached the employers to support her with her monthly wages at the household level. This led to an achievement where the emp loyers agreed to support them till the lockdown restrictions were lifted post which she joined back to work unconditionally.   Ranchi, Jharkhand Domestic workers have been facilitated in understanding their wages according to their work hours and days. Therefore, a regular meeting with Agewan and the trade committee members has been undertaken to understand how the rate chart should be normally developed by the domestic workers. Therefore a campaign was conducted by the Agewan and Domestic Worker trade group members and trade leaders by conducting focus group discussions in areas from where the domestic workers go to work to different areas. firstly to understand that in current days how domestic workers are getting their work according to their work hours. Through the focus group discussion, SEWA learnt about their household counts, work hours in each household, the amount they receive, number of rooms they take care of, types of service they provide to the household, and distance of workplace area. Now in the next phase, the domestic workers will be facilitated and mobilised to bring the rates to a common rate so that each can do equal work and get an equal rate.    Campaign on MGNREGA:  The Right to Food network observed a 14-day campaign from 15th September to 1st October 2021. As a part of the initiative, agewans of SEWA West Bengal took part in the campaign. In Murshidabad and Malda districts SEWA members conducted poster campaigns and submitted letters to the nodal officer mentioning their demands of get ting work under the MGNREGA scheme thereby letting the voices reach the duty bearers and making them accountable.  Around 250 members received work through this campaign which ensured their Right to livelihood. ---X--- Engagement with Y outh  The inclusion of youth in transforming their communities by organizing them into groups is fundamental for the growth and development of the community as a whole. Years of Engagement with the youth have helped in developing the next generation of leadership at the grassroots who are capable of addressing their community-level issues and advocating for the fulfilment of rights of women involved in the informal economy thereby leading the SEWA movement forward. The training(s) and meetings have provided them with a platform to learn new skills, build upon their knowledge and be aware of their rights and entitlements In Jharkhand, as a part of learning from Bengal, local youth groups have been created to recognise their issues, address them and develop the second SEWA generation. Thus from 2021 SEWA Jharkhand started organising the adolescent girls as well, started conducting informal meetings with them in their area to know them more and to also know what they know about informal work, SEWA as a movement of women workers and the challenges their mothers face to earn a decent work and remain resilient at times of extreme crisis like the pandemic or flood. For them, it was not new to see their mother gathering for meetings, and discussions, under the SEWA banner, so the Adolescent girls were well aware that their mother worked as a domestic worker, construction worker and agriculture worker and they are a member of SEWA and their mothers are organised by SEWA for their trade righteous and issues. so understanding SEWA was not hard for them. During their, meetings they are encouraged to bring us their issues as an adolescent like marriageable age, Sexual and Reproductive health, choice in life, education, skill and employment. Today in both the districts in Jharkhand, Ranchi and Hazaribagh 45 adolescent girls are part of SEWA now and recently by the end of the year 2021 formal meetings were conducted in both the district SEWA office for the orientation of SEWA work and to find opportunities to know how to work with the Adolescent girls in Jharkhand. The girls were started involved in KOBO tool training (Data collection training) where they will work on surveys in future to be conducted by SEWA.    Youth Group meetings and Training While SEWA historically considers itself at the intersection of the labour movement and the womens movement, the expansion of work under the Youth leadership development program has allowed us to deepen our involvement in these movements through the adoption of new praxes, as well as increasing   our integration into work around public health. We do this through expanding our core approach of rights-based mobilising, and building on it through the incorporation of voices and agency of young girls who then join the labour movement and the womens movement as empowered actors, right from the onset. Objective 2: Principal accomplishments SEWA operates empowerment centres known as SEW A Shakti Kendras in all districts across the two states. SEWA's presence and operations in communities are anchored on the SSKs. They connect community people with government programmes and schemes related to microfinance, health, job, and skill development opportunities, and they provide resources, support, and information to women for their economic and social growth. The SSK is also important as a last-mile delivery mechanism for social security and welfare systems, supporting women and their families in accessing them. These centres, which are staffed by a woman from the local community, give assurance and assistance to help women negotiate the application processes and receive public welfare benefits. SEWA Shakti Kendra acts as a bridge between the government and the community members. Through the SSK community members became aware not only of their rights but also of the way to access them. At present, through the programme, the states have developed around 8 SSKs under the OAK programme, overall 9 SSKs at present supported through various programmes. The inputs given have bolstered the SSK in ensuring  An increased outreach, covering wider schemes and ensuring maximum benefits are received through the Kendras, while also including the expansion of services by catering to the community needs through camps, aagevan mobilisation, and door-to-door visits  Inputs towards the development of staff capacity on handling multiple aspects attached to the SSK, along with developing the SSK In-charge by identifying young leaders in the community.  Working towards stronger connections with stakeholders, and relevant government departments.  Regularised and centralised database management system. Summary: In 2022, Pratham expanded into North Bengal with a focus on providing vocational training to youth from tea garden communities in Darjeeling, Kalimpong, Cooch Behar, Jalpaiguri, and Alipurduar districts. The strategic location of the project also ties well with Prathams intention to expand its presence in the East and North-Eastern parts of India. Key Outcomes: The program significantly impacted the lives of tea garden youth, offering them stable employment with salaries ranging from Rs. 9,500 to Rs. 14,264 per month, along with accommodation and food. Community engagement initiatives, including tool-kit exhibitions and camps, fostered trust and enhanced foundational skills in reading, math, and English among children and youth in tea garden communities. Collaborations with organizations like Transform Trade, Swaniti Initiatives, FPA, Nazdeeq, and KABIL enhanced community mobilization and resource-sharing efforts. Pratham's funding efforts from CSR initiatives, HNIs, and foundations are poised to further strengthen this intervention, ensuring sustainability. In summary, Pratham's expansion into North Bengal in its first year of the multi-year grant has made substantial progress towards its objectives of providing vocational training, securing formal employment, and fostering community engagement in tea garden communities. The program has transformed individual lives but also laid the foundation for lasting positive impacts on the region's youth and their families in the coming years of the intervention. The communities residing in North Bengal face precarious living conditions, largely reliant on employment opportunities presented by tea plantation owners. Challenges such as meager wages, seasonal employment fluctuations, constraints imposed by plantation owners, and a dearth of alternative income avenues have long been endemic. Pratham's proactive approach seeks to address these issues directly by engaging with the youth of tea garden areas. Keeping in mind the niche challenges of human trafficking faced by the tea-garden communities, the program embeds special counseling sessions and end-to-end migration support for youth who get placed out of their district. This in-turns is geared towards tackling the issue of unsafe migration and trafficking. Pratham's commitment extends beyond North Bengal, as we aim to expand our endeavors throughout West Bengal, informed by our ongoing programs and a deep understanding of industry  Oak Progress Report.    3 demands and community needs. The set target for the current year involves training 320 youth from tea garden regions, endowing them with the skills and knowledge necessary for thriving within industry-specific job placements. The aim is to secure industry-relevant job opportunities for 80% of these trained individuals, effectively creating a transformative impact on both individual lives and the larger community. In introducing the vocational training vertical within this new geography, we strategically leveraged our existing network to establish a presence. The selection of the training centers location was meticulously considered, with factors like proximity to the tea-garden communities, availability of essential infrastructure, and a high demand for vocational training playing pivotal roles in the decision-making process. Prior to setting up the establishment, we engaged with various stakeholders, including the local community, government authorities, local NGOs, and potential employers, funding partnerships that would later prove instrumental. Placement Insights: Pratham has a robust placement and post-placement support system to help youth have a smooth transition for the formal workforce after completing their training. Need Assessment Study: A quantitative baseline survey was conducted in 73 villages across Darjeeling, Kalimpong, Alipurduar, Coochbehar, and Jalpaiguri districts from 23rd- 27th November 2022. The overarching goal of the survey was to establish the current scenario in the tea-garden region in terms of the need for skill development & alternate safe employment opportunities for youth. In addition to the community survey, an industry survey was conducted to gauge the industry demand for the skilled workforce in Hospitality and Automotive sectors in North Bengal. Additionally, qualitative interviews were conducted with 27 Households across 3 districts- Jalpaiguri, Darjeeling and Alipurduar exploring the themes like- Employment types & pathways in tea-garden communities, Challenges pertaining to current employment, Perception of the community on different employment types- formal jobs, labor, self-employment, gig opportunities, Perception/opinion of the community regarding aspiration of employment for the current generation. Physical activities started in the first quarter of 2022 and before that activities were limited to online platforms due to Covid induced global pandemic. However, five physical advocacy workshops have been conducted with each hub partner comprising on an average 40 participants from the respective partner and community members identified during the process. NCAS participated in regular meetings for planning review and coordination with hub partners along with annual review of the project. Each workshop was dedicated to explore the community issues and how the community can address it themselves based on strength and weakness. Vulnerable groups such as farmers, women, children, and migrants were identified along with their vulnerabilities such as repairing of river embankment, domestic violence, child marriages, gender discriminations, drinking water, forced migration due to lack of local opportunities, prevalence of anemia in adolescent girls, etc. Sundarban is delta region where river Ganga flows into Bay of Bengal sea. Islands surrounded by saline sea water are the primary characteristics of local geography. Every year during monsoon or cyclone saline water breaks the weakening river embankment and enters into agricultural fields and fish ponds destroying not only current crops but the farm itself. This makes the farm unproductive for the next six or more years subject to intensity of salinity. This causes huge loss to the local farmers hence; they want to repair and strengthen the river embankment. Farmers are also struggling to access the fair market price of their farm produce such as fish, vegetables etc. These issues are interlinked and need to be looked at holistically and ecologically sustainable manner. One group has already started the river embankment repairing work as an alternative model rooted in traditional knowledge and practices by planting local trees and shrubs tolerant to saline water.  State agencies are concretizing the river embankment and making the fluid ecological interface between water and land very hard and impenetrable. As an alternative to concretization of river embankment we organized "Rethinking River Embankment", a field exposure visit for community members and staffs, so that community members can take local and ecologically sustainable initiative in their respective villages to protect their life and livelihood. We conducted NCAS's Resource Person's meet for ideation to pursue in the next phase of the project.     7.c. Challenges and obstacles. Collaboration of domain expert institutions in the community development program at Sundarban as hub partners is new experience for many and that too through a community-oriented approach. This initiative has faced numerous challenges and consciously reviewed collectively to evolve for better. The platform of the steering committee falling short to include community representative  Oak Progress Report.    3 and field level staff in the decision-making process. Communitys voice must be heard and respected at each level of decision-making process in the community-oriented approach. Hub partners struggled to reorient themselves towards the community-oriented approach. Their prior experience was limited to the service delivery, reoriented staff and organizational understanding towards this approach was very challenging and particularly to assimilate it. This also raises many questions, how do we understand community-led processes and how to include the community in the process, given that community is not one unit but many groups subject to gender, caste, class etc. Ensuring community participation in the process has so many contours to negotiate at the village level. Asking participants particularly women and girls to stay outside of home for a night to participate in a workshop was a herculean challenge itself to overcome. Another challenge which will take time to overcome is to help the community to realize that this initiative is not to address your concerns but to empower the community to address their concerns. Political contour at the village level is most difficult to manage and yet partners are struggling to figure out a strategy to deal with this. Physical accessibility of the villages scattered in islands are very limited. There are many villages which cant be accessed by roads but through boats. There is also sketchy infrastructure such as electricity and mobile networks in some areas. However, this initiative needs to address this divide through a very robust strategy to deal with this kind of challenges during execution.   8.

PR_Terre_des_hommes_Lausanne_AddreTraffT.Progress Against Objectives: Progress Against Objectives Under each expected project objective, briefly explain your progress in reaching the objective and its results, and discuss any changes you propose to the project goals or objectives with the PO.  7.1.a. Objective 1 Institutionalized practices in partner organizations contribute to strengthened systems to prevent and protect Children and Young People at risk of or affected by unsafe migration and assist sustainable reintegration of survivors of trafficking and exploitation.   7.1.b. Objective 1: Principal accomplishments The project emphasized importance of gender responsive approach to child protection issues and services at the system level to reduce stigma against transgender children and survivors of trafficking and sexual exploitation. Partners are collectivized to act as a network advocating for the survivors right to accessible support services and creation of local safety nets for prevention of unsafe migration. The project built capacities of CSOs to use tools for a child centred reintegration process and increased acceptance by government duty bearers and service providers.  411 frontline workers demonstrated skills on child handling and dealing with difficult behaviour of survivors following child safeguarding principles through use of tools and learnings from project trainings. 165 children reported their views are sought for and incorporated into decision making and care planning. Anecdotes from the children indicate how the tool is supporting them to reflect and share their emotions. 383 government duty bearers shared positive feedback towards the tools and guidelines developed under this project. Decentralised resource pools at district level are established, providing assistance to victims of unsafe migration. 45 inter-agency meetings conducted  and 391 cases were supported through this collaboration, which ensured that the voices of the children are heard and the stakeholders in the ecosystem are involved to ensure that Children and Young People (CYPs) recieve quality services. Safeguarding Community of Practice has been established with 54 members to promote safety in the process of reintegration. 379 child care professionals increased knowledge of Child Safeguarding. CSOs were capacitated to support Mental Health, functioning and Psychosocial Wellbeing of survivors of trafficking. 243 frontline workers increased their knowledge on Psychosocial Resilience Framework and 220 front line workers are now able to monitor Psychosocial Wellbeing of CYPs including survivors by using tools developed by Tdh, UNICEF and a checklist developed by the partners.   7.1.c. Objective 1: Shortfalls Multiple challenges were faced during the implementation of the BECOME Tool by the frontline workers. The main challenges and feedback given on the use of the tool was that it is  too time consuming and many times Children and Youth in Migration (CYiM) with whom the tool is applied loose concentration or are unwilling to tell his/her story to be able to complete the process. The partner organisations are working at various stages of the entire spectrum of the anti-trafficking space, and come with different levels of capacity and skill sets. For this reason it was challenging to build content around trainings that accommodated the needs of all. For conducting the online training sessions with the frontline workers, one of the challenge was consistent internet  connectivity while the level of understanding among all the frontline workers were not found at the same level.   There could have been a more robust and s ystematic follow up on support for the trained social workers within the partner organisations by Tdh, however   Tdh faced challenges with high staff turnover of the tained social workers within the partner organisations. Inter-agency resource pool formatio n is yet to be done by 6 partner organisations who are comparatively small and have a lack of funding and inadequate information on district level resources. It was also found that these organizations faced challenges in finding trained personnel who can develop the resource pool. In Year 1 the overall challenge was the impact of COVID-19 second and third wave in the implementation and changes in the FCRA Rules which caused a 6 month delay to starting the field level implementation, which only started from July 2021 onwards. Hence, most of the partners were not able to complete the target within the 2022 annual plan.   7.2.a. Objective 2 Community level safety nets are established and functional to protect Children and Youth in Migration (CYiM) and support reintegration of the victims of unsafe migration/exploitation/ trafficking in 70 Gram Panchayats of 12 districts.   7.2.b. Objective 2: Principal accomplishments 103 multi-sectorial coordination meetings and 76 liasons completed with various formal and informal child protection duty bearers at district and block level. Through these, stakeholders in the ecosystem are now involved to ensure CYP recieve quality, responsive and stigma-free services. 551 formal and informal child protection duty bearers can identify child protection concerns and are aware of their responsibilities and referral pathway. 290 child protection concerns were raised and referred by the formal and informal child protection duty bearers within this reporting period. 3544 CYiM participated in leadership training, among whom 1850 children were identified by the partner to be supported to join local Child Protection Committees (CPCs) 408 children participated in local child protection committee meetings. 231 child prot ection concerns raised and reported by CYP leaders to appropriate authorities. For inclusion of the CYiM in the CPCs, 49 advocacy initiatives were completed by partner organisations with District Level Child Protection Society for making the CPCs function al in the areas where they are not functional at all or partially functioning and regarding inclusion of CYiM leaders in the CPCs and ensuring child participation. Partner organisations met with formal and informal district, ward and village level child protection duty bearesand organized consultations at the district level for establishment of CPCs. The CYiM prepared and placed a draft during the VLCPC/WLCPC formation meetings to the Panchayat Pradhan as well for formation and inclusion of CYPs in the CPC meetings. 20 CPCs at village and ward level and 1 CPC at block level have been formed in West Bengal and Jharkhand through initiatives taken by the partner organisations. The inclusion of the CYPs in the CPC meetings helped raise the voices of the children on the issues affecting their lives and to advocate for changes.   7.2.c. Objective 2: Shortfalls   The overall challenge was the impact of COVID-19 and changes in the FCRA Rules which led to a 6 month delay in implementing field level activities.   Due to the West Bengal State elections,   the State Commission for Protection of Child Rights and other institutional structures like Child Welfare Committee and the District Child Protection Unit were not function for a period of time which m ade the advocacy work very challenging. Advocating for the mainstreaming of the tools to be incorporated within the Juvenile Justice (JJ) system in Jharkhand was not possible, and  collaboration with the State government of Jharkhand is still ongoing for steering the district level and media advocacies. The project was able to initiate organisational level advocacy and cluster level advocacy work at the district level; however, the planned state level work could not be achieved. The Empowerplus Application and Livelihood Pre-conditioning could not be dessiminated by the partner organisations in 2022as the application is under upgradation for additional features based on user feedback. Addirionally once of the core consultants working on this passed away from  COVID and retrieving and getting another person to take the work forward caused further delays. As mentioned above in the principal accomplishment of objective 2, the partner organisations have taken up various initiatives at district and local level for making the CPCs functional in West Bengal and Jharkhand. Despite the initiatives taken, some CPCs are still not functional in some of the intervention areas for which the inclusion of CYiM leaders in the CPCs and ensuring child participation was not 100% achieved as targeted.     7.3.a. Objective 3 Children and Young People at risk of or affected by unsafe migration are resilient to challenge harmful social norms that perpetuate violence and stigma against the survivors of trafficking and exploitation.   7.3.b. Objective 3: Principal accomplishments Community safe spaces were created in 70 locations for fostering discussions and reflection on gender, sexuality and norms. The project engaged 2,054 CYP to increase their knowledge on Gender and Sexuality, risks and support services. 991 CYiM realized appropriate information related to coping with internal reactions, 334 CYiM reported a sense of calm and decreased negative emotions. 1,415 CYiM were able to identify risks they could face, 1,458 CYiM identified the institutions that can respond to their safety concerns and they know how to approach them, 2,941 CYiM demonstrated critical thinking/problem solving skills and 264 survivors and CYiM reported increased connectedness with peers, family, and kinship network. The above outputs were achieved as a result of 421 trainings on Gender and Sexuality, 310 trainings on Continuum of Care Approach, Socio Ecological Approachn of MHPSS, and 2464 workshops and reflection sessions with girls and 1811 workshops and reflection sessions with boys. Increased collective actions were observed at the community level through theatre, sports, arts by girls, boys, parents and survivors of trafficking to challenge harmful practices. 227 community based social  actions were organised by CYiM on gender based harmful practices and stigma associated with trafficking. 3,032 influential leaders and communicators participated in social action events, among them 398 influential leaders and communicators made public declarations against gender based harmful practices and have shown support to survivors. 669 community male members are able to recognise negative gender norms behind revictimization of survivors and harmful practices; like forced marriage and 564 male family members showed support to   girls by preventing early marriage and byapproaching survivors and encouraging them to live a stigma free life.   7.3.c. Objective 3: Shortfalls Development of  Social Behaviour Change guideline based on global guidelines with techniques and tips followed is ongoing in collaboration with WINDCHANGERS, after the completion of the same, partners will be provided training on how to use the materials. Contextualisation of the stories based on the feedback from the partners and children has taken longer than anticipated, however we strongly feel that this process is critical, and therefore have not taken shortcuts to speed the process up. The understanding on gender and sexuality is varied among the project partner organisations, where a was observed among the frontline workers when they initiated discussions on gender and sexuality. For many, they felt comfortable to talk about sexuality, menstrual health, safe and unsafe touch. In conducting reflection sessions with boys, the partner organisations shared a challenge relating to the drop out. This drop out rates of boys are much higher among the boys in the age group 15 -18 years and above upto 24 years since the boys are mostly migrating out from the villages with their  families for seasonal works. In conducting reflection sessions with the girls also related to drop out, Girls who are in the age group 18- 24 years are getting married or migrating with families for work, or going out for educational purpose since there is no proper infrastructure for higher studies in most of the intervention areas. One of the challenge faced by the partners at field level is getting in touch with the male members and bringing all the male members in one place to initiate discussions. The male members are the main breadwinners of the family and most of them migrate out of the village in search of work and are therefor unavailable.    8.

Progress Report for the period of 1/07/2021 to 31/10/22     During Second wave of Covid-19, we started working in the field to form community groups. As many issues were discussed during Micro level planning, the groups started forming based on various issues associated with different communities like farmers groups for agriculture related issues, women groups for livelihood related issues, adolescent groups for child marriage or migration related issues. Through general issue discussion and introducing the objective of this project, several women and adolescents girls related issues like negligence to menstruation health, early child marriage, school drop out, early pregnancy, random child birth at home, gender based violence(especially domestic violence)  etc. Considering these issues a few mixed adult women and adolescent groups were formed and Mukti field ACV staff started organizing several workshops on gender discriminations with the help of various participatory tools supported by Rupantaran and Prajaak. 8 Adolescent girls boys and 5 women groups( total 320 groups members) got support to build their perspective on gender related issues and gradually started identifying gender discrimination in their personal life. The basic sensitization workshops also conducted among adult men groups. As a result, women started taking active role in the collective discussions making process and the woman man ratio in every meetings are nearly became 1:1 as other men are also started taking positive initiative to create a safe and non judging space for women. Adolescent groups have also started identifying their issues and through root cause analysis, they are getting a clear understanding on gender discrimination and how it impacts their lives( issues came during discussion like - restriction in higher education for girls, mobility restrictions, gender role etc)  As an outcome, Heramba Gopalpur women group joined in a community led event organized on 15th Aug 2022. For Heramba Gopalpur women group, it was the first time for them when they participated in a rally and slogan writing. In the main part of the program they also gave a speech on Independence day.     7.1.c. Objective 1 Challenges and obstacles. Oak Progress Report.    3   During the community groups formation, we initially faced a huge political challenges as most of the group members were belong to  different vulnerable groups, the ruling party members started giving objections to conduct any meetings regarding their issues. For these political pressure, a large number of members started dropping out from the groups and refuse to take part into any discussions. At that time, the whole ACV working team started approaching to the panchayat members to join the meetings to understand the objective of this project. But due to the presence of the Panchayat members, some kind of pseudo domination in each discussion started taking places and these discussions spaces turned into a space for ruling and opponent party members and the real issues left undiscussed. In such situations a few perspective building workshops conducted by the facilitation of  ACV team among all the groups to develop the capacity of the community members as well as the Panchayat members to understand the concept of right based and community led approach and to develop the relationship between community members , ACV team members and Panchayat or other powerful stakeholders( teachers, doctors, health workers). With several set of meeting and discussion or activities ( perspective building support and module provided  by Praxis, Rupantaran, DRCSC, NCAS and Prajaak) , the groups became stable and the power influence tends to decrease over time.    In the beginning of 2nd year ( 1/07/2021),  new field staff and program coordinator were recruited who were not completely aligned with the project goal. Hence, it became a bit challenging to the ACV staff to be the facilitators and as a result, most of the proposed solutions started become partially influenced by the project staff itself such as the decisions taken by collective discussion on training topics, scheduling the meetings, issue identification etc. This challenge gradually solved with the continue handholding support of other ACV resource partners and internal staff meeting and orientation program.                          7.2.a. The sensitization program performed by Mukti ACV field staff helped those women to understand the reason of these issues through but it takes a lot more time to develop their confidence to talk about those issues freely in front of other community members. In order to achieve the safe environment for all the women members from different communities(Farmers, daily labour, Migrant workers etc) many orientation program conducted and as a result, women started taking initiatives to raise voice against discrimination. Initiative taken by the Women collective - 1. Rally to raise awareness on gender based discrimination, slogan writing 2. Motivational speech on woman's empowerment by women members, 3. Initiative taken by the Adolescents groups -  1.Both boys and girls equally participated in rally to raise awareness on  menstruation health related taboo and developing a street play group to raise awareness on early child marriage and Child labour (Adolescent boys are forced to start working to support their family from early ages and this situation increases the possibility of unsafe migration) . 2. Active role has been taken by the adolescent groups in community led advocacy on river embankment related issues to collect the required evidence.3. Adolescent groups are also planning to take initiative to reduce the negative impact of unnecessary usage of social media and extreme addiction of online gaming in the youth community.          7.2.c. Oak Progress Report.    5     Initially we faced several challenge to mobilize the women and develop their confidence to take any initiative to raise voice against the violation of their rights and various gender based discriminations. During the 15th Aug program planning, all the woman's collective(5groups - 120 women) refused to participate actively in awareness program as they were concerned about the comments they might have received for stepping out from their home to participate in  such community events and as a result they ended up suggesting the Adolescent groups(8 groups - 100 boys and 120 girls) to attend this event to fulfill the purpose. To overcome such challenges, we requested these women groups to arrange a few meetings to talk about this issue. To resolve this,  Mukti ACV team facilitated the risk assessment process and orientation programs to develop a clear perspective about the consequences of their initiative and who and how the others will be impacted through these. With several approach, a few women from each groups convinced to take lead to mobilize other women and they successfully completed the event.  In community led advocacy group which is working on river embankment issue, several challenges were experienced by the vulnerable community representatives during the larger village level committee formation. As river embankment issue is one of the major issues in Heramba gopalpur area which is untreated by local Govt for past few years, people from most effected communities refused to talk about their issues to find a possible solution through collective discussion as they were more concern about their approach might get wrong and they will become more vulnerable. Hence a conflict created in this village level committee and they started deforming it. To resolve such issues, the objective of community led advocacy again properly defined among these committee members by the ACV facilitators and by the support of NCAS member, the committee started becoming united        7.3.a. Oak Progress Report.    6     The communities which are relatively vulnerable based on their livelihood have been included in this initiative. The process started with several focus group discussion to understand the  current livelihood status of several communities  and the challenges they are facing right now. Through  multiple meetings,  women groups turned into the most vulnerable groups as they all are directly or indirectly involve in several livelihoods(especially farming, fishing) but don't have minimum agency over the earnings and the second most vulnerable community in Heramba Gopalpur area is the farmers community. Earning through farming became one of the unstable options as in past 4 years, people of Heramba Gopalpur experienced four disasters(Amphan, Phaani, Bulbul and Yaash) which created flooding situations in their area. This situation mostly forced the farmers community (specially male farmers with limited land) to become seasonal migrant workers to run their families. On other hand, the degree of vulnerability of this farmers community is also high due to the lack of knowledge about cropping as most of the lands are only used for monocropping so the net worth of annual produce become low as respect to the need of a farmer's family. This situation also leads most of the farmers to become a migrant workers for most of the period of time in a year. In such situation, to revive the soil condition, organic farming training has been provided to almost 300 farmers where around 30% farmers (including women and men) started making organic fertilizer and pesticides to reduce farming expenses.   And among the women and mixed groups, these groups started exploring suitable options according to their resource and abilities. Through several participatory approach, few livelihood options came up from these groups such as chicken rearing (especially native breed) indigenous seed collection and selling, crab culture , sanitary pad production, paper plate making, scented stick and candle making etc. Along with skill development training, several orientation program and marketing skill development process also going on among these groups. The training needs came up through local demand and supply chain analysis. Presently farmers groups(Women and men) and other interested members from different communities received chicken rearing training and started chicken farming in a small scale.       7.3.c. Objective 3 Challenges and obstacles. We expect that the work toward grant objectives may not occur as originally planned due to internal and external factors. Oak Progress Report.    7   The concept of having an additional livelihood option in their own locality is largely ignored in various communities in Sundarbans. As farming is the primary livelihood for ~85% of population in Heramba Gopalpur GP and most of the lands are used for mono cropping, for the additional income purpose, most of the people (especially male members of the family) became engage in seasonal fishing or became migrant worker for a long period of time in the year. These issues were observed during the FGD with the farmers, fisherman and daily labour groups. Through meetings and  discussion, as different additional livelihood options were introduced to these groups, mostly male members were refused to take interest for further discussion or initiatives. In such situation, the additional livelihood implementation initiative started with the women groups who are involved with different livelihood ( farming, daily labour, fishing). Through new FGH(Focus Group Discussion) , several needs emerged but also a clear demand came from the communities regarding financial and marketing support for any production related business ideas such as Pickle, Scented Sticks, Soft toys etc. Then the ACV team started taking different approach to build capacity of the communities to understand the local market demands and supply chain for developing own ideas according to the needs of the local market. To develop such capacity, several tools were given to help them understand the current market demands. Parallelly, a few orientation programs were conducted to help them understand their role to sustain their livelihood.  These all initiatives are gradually helping to eliminate the concept of dependency to third parties for raw material collection, product manufacturing and marketing.   Presently , the woman groups mapped and analyzed the basic local market demands and according to that, they have selected two livelihood options - 1. Sanitary pad manufacturing and marketing 2. Chicken rearing(native breed). Hence to establish their business, the woman groups are making strategies to overcome these challenges.    8.

In this reporting period, the adolescent and women collectives have been formed having 300 members and around 200 members respectively. Presently, the collectives are going through a cycle of perspective and skill enhancing and action. The adolescent collectives took actions on the issues identified & prioritised by them which includes survey on gender-based work division & menstruation, theater on early marriage & menstruation, rally by the young people to build public opinion on anti-trafficking issues. In Gopalnagar GP, the VLCPC a community-based committee under the ICPS was existing, but in a dormant stage. Objective 1 Progress. What progress has been made toward the above grant objective(s) over the last grant period?
