In Year 1, we reflected and examined our previous approach, and re-strategized to make necessary modifications in line with the projects vision. We pivoted our communication strategy to focus on the deeper aspects of SRH, modified our outreach methodology to incorporate behavior change principles, and focused on better understanding the attitudinal barriers of health staff that hamper service provision. While on one hand, these changes represent a significant strategic shift aligning with the project's intent, they also provided immense organizational learning. As we began implementing this revised approach, we saw better engagement with the community and our improved ability to elicit more meaningful responses from our audience that will be helpful in driving the desired behavior change. Summary of progress on project outcomes: 1. Trained 12 youth leaders on new communication strategy  Re-designed our communication strategy to focus on rights, barriers and gender using a behavioral change approach (details in 7.1.c).  Conducted four-day residential training followed by three-day practice for youth leaders and their supervisor.  Youth leaders initiated community outreach using participatory interactions to make young people more active participants in their own behavior change. 2. Oriented 9,410 young women and 7,640 young men on life skills, rights, and gender Young women  Engaged with young women with focus on SRH rights, barriers faced in exercising these rights and their aspirations for change.  The sessions sparked interest among young women and led to provoking questions  on curbs on movement or clothing choices unlike male counterparts, on restrictions during menstruation, and around other practices that make them uncomfortable. The discussions set the foundation for subsequent rounds that will build their skills to communicate these issues with adults and partners.  Promoted our AI-powered chatbot (Disha Didi) and conducted SRH sessions in schools reaching 1,800 girls. Young men  Conducted sessions with men on relevant SRH information, particularly contraception, and emphasized their role in supporting women's SRH.  Used an interactive game to emphasize the connection between reproductive health and finances. This encouraged discussions on the importance of family planning giving segway  Oak Progress Report.    3 to deeper discussions  including adopting safe sexual practices and using contraception themselves for the benefits it brings to their relationships and families. Also conducted couple counselling with non-users of contraceptive  youth leaders reported that 2,100 of 2,700 couples have adopted a modern contraceptive (self-reported), with nearly 55% using condom. 3. Sensitized 1,840 family members on supporting young womens SRH Sensitized mothers and mothers-in-law on SRH-related barriers that came up during discussions with young women. While a lot of these emanated from long-held beliefs and traditionally followed practices, they also include common misconceptions that hinder adoption of healthy SRH practices by young women  youth leaders addressed these during their sessions. 4. Strengthened two public health facilities to offer youth friendly SRH services Oriented all relevant staff in intervention facilities (four CAC providers and two counsellors) on provisions of the MTP (Amendment) Act, 2021 and provision of youth-responsive SRH services, including abortions to young women. 5. Strengthened six HWCs to offer SRH services and referral  Based on district officials request, conducted district-level contraceptive training for 10 community health officers (CHOs) to expand their role in contraceptive service provision  the training was attended by the civil surgeon and other officials, who appreciated the training.  Conducted virtual orientation for 20 CHOs and a telemedicine hub doctor for initiating provision of injectable contraceptive through eSanjeevani (federal governments telemedicine program).  Conducted facility strengthening, including provision of equipment, facilitating IEC materials, strengthening documentation, and introduction to the referral mechanism. We expect that the work toward grant objectives may not occur as originally planned due to internal and external factors.  Please share a candid assessment of areas of challenge and learning and whether any adjustments were made. Key learnings and insights:  Communication strategy  Developed in collaboration with a social and behavior change communication consultant, the revised communication strategy emphasizes on key principles  rights, power, space, participation and inclusion  and works to address key factors that influence behavior, including social norms, beliefs and values. The youth leaders are on a learning curve implementing these newer concepts in the community, and  Oak Progress Report.    4 we are continuously adapting and refining the strategy (including combining modules) based on their experience and learnings.  Working with the SRH framework  The revised strategy meant a major shift in the community engagement approach of youth leaders, with focus on understanding the target audience's attitudes, beliefs, and motivators, and working on changing SRH-related behaviors keeping these in mind. This approach brought forth unanticipated responses from the communities, including seeking solutions for structural barriers (such as movement restrictions) and other allied issues (like child marriage). This in turn has meant more intense mentorship by IDF to equip youth leaders to manage such conversations. Keeping this in view, we have planned periodic capacity building of youth leaders to enable them to effectively moderate such conversations and offer support/referrals.  Prevailing attitudinal barriers among providers  We introduced a tool  an adaptation of Ipass Stigmatizing Attitudes, Beliefs and Actions Scale (SABAS)  to measure health staffs attitudes, perceptions and stigma related to abortion and contraception. The tool comprises of 25 statements that the respondent rates on a Likert scale which is used to measure three important dimensions, negative stereotyping, exclusion and discrimination, and fear of contagion from those who associate with abortion and contraception. The tool helped us discover prevailing negative beliefs and attitudes that hinder service provision  such as women who use birth spacing may become promiscuous or having an abortion may become a habit for women  that we will work on addressing.  Safe spaces  Youth leaders created six safe spaces in anganwadi centres and schools to provide young girls an environment where they could have confidential and non-judgmental conversations about SRH; these were visited by over 560 young women and girls. While we received a positive response, we recognized the limitation of this approach with dependence on youth leaders and the spaces themselves not being accessible by young girls independently. We are re-visiting this and will test an approach where the safe space facilitates unrestricted access  for example, creating online forums to facilitate these conversations, encouraging leadership by the yuva saathis who can work with their peers to identify other such spaces and facilitate these conversations.    7.2.a. In Year 1, we laid the foundation for our intervention by conducting a community survey and facility-level assessment to identify gaps and better understand the needs of our target audience. We strengthened the capacity of healthcare providers and community intermediaries to provide youth-responsive services and streamlined SRH services, especially at health and wellness centers for improved access. With this strong foundation and our outcome indicators in place, we are now prepared to focus our community-based efforts to improve SRH behaviors and practices. 1. Selected intervention areas for community interventions: Working in consultation with district and block health officials, we selected six gram panchayats covering 23 villages in the three intervention blocks for community outreach activities prioritizing panchayats that were further from health facilities and had poor service access. We also selected three facilities  RH Rudranagar, RH Dwariknagar and RH Madhabnagar  for facility-level interventions. 2. Conducted community-based assessment: To assess knowledge, behavior, practices and access barriers that young women and adolescents face, we conducted a cross-sectional community survey with 767 respondents (including adolescent girls, young women and men) in the three intervention blocks. Some key findings:  Young women and girls have high level of stigma, myths, and misconceptions related to SRH issues  most of them around menstruation (69%) and abortion (54%)  Agency is low  irrespective of marital status, young women and girls majorly rely on others to take decisions on education, marriage, healthcare, and pregnancy.  They have poor negotiating ability  more than one fourth adolescents reported poor ability to negotiate with parents regarding continuing education or time of marriage.  About one third of male respondents reported having a positive outlook towards womens SRH. 3. Developed outcome indicators: Based on the community assessment and our understanding of the current challenges, we determined outcome indicators and the expected level of change we anticipate by the project end. An expansion of SRH Programme for Indigent Populations' Rights and Empowerment. The Project ASPIRE supported by Oak Foundation is being implemented in West Bengal through FPA Indias Kalchini and Kolkata Branches. It aims to expand access to sexual and reproductive health and empower individuals and communities to exercise their sexual and reproductive rights with gender equality, economic empowerment and thus poverty alleviation. The project has been implemented in West Bengal through FPA Indias Kalchini branch located in north of Bengal and FPA India Kolkata branch which is catering to the population of south Bengal. Under the project, FPA India Kalchini branch has expanded the geographical reach with SRH care in Madarihat block of Alipurduar District. The Satellite clinic established by FPA India in Madarihat under one of the specially funded projects for comprehensive abortion care was closed down after the funding was stopped, with Oak Foundations partial grant support, this clinic has been revamped with the staff, commodities, and maintenance. It is now being accessed by the people in and around Madarihat block. This block is divided into a diverse culture of different communities like Bengali, Nepali, Muslim, Adivasi, Rava, Mech, Garo & Toto, having their origin back to different places in India. The services provided at the Satellite clinic are being accessed by these communities and referral for SRH care has been done with FPA Indias Kalchini RHFPC.  With an expansion under ASPIRE project, Kalchini branch has taken up 17 new tea gardens in Madarihat and also covering 9 new tea gardens in Kalchini block which were not regularly covered due to accessibility issues. The expansion is estimated to cover an additional 2,50,000 population together. FPA India Kolkata branch has been working in urban, peri-urban areas covering slum population in and around Kolkata including Howrah, Hooghly as well as parts of Sunderbans closer to the satellite clinics of FPA India Kolkata branch near Lake garden, Topsia and Rajarhat. Under ASPIRE project, it intervenes in south Bengal through to 5 selected blocks of Sunderbans, i.e. Basanti, Canning, Gosaba, Kultoli in 24 south Parganas and Hingalganj block in north 24 Parganas. With an expansion in 24 Parganas, Kolkata would be reaching out to approximately 8,00,000 new population over the period of project. Expansion includes working with women, men, transgender population, female and male sex workers  in selected areas of key population such as Sonagachi. Swaniti Initiative conducted a baseline study to determine the accessibility of Government Social Protection schemes by tea garden workers, across gardens in four districts of West Bengal i.e Darjeeling, Alipurduar, Kochbihar, and Jalpaiguri.  The study included a sample of 7488 respondents from these four districts of West Bengal. The study was conducted using three methods: Household surveys, semi-structured interviews, and focused group discussions. The data was collected by Swaniti team and volunteers through digital intervention of Surveymana survey management tool.    Using this report as a backbone, Swaniti designed interventions across all the 4 districts mentioned above.        7.1.c. Objective 1 Challenges and obstacles. Please share a candid assessment of areas of challenge and learning and whether any adjustments were made. Based on our findings some of which are: complete lack of grievance redressal mechanisms as reported by 100% of the respondents and 1 out of every 4 respondents had incorrect information printed on their Aadhaar Card, the following challenges were faced:  Challenges:  The study faced challenges during data collection, with respondents initially reluctant to share information. However, our swaniti team  and volunteers were able to explain the purpose of the study and its potential benefits to the tea workers.   Oak Progress Report.    3  Access to information was another challenge, with most respondents needing to be made aware of important social protection schemes. The surveyors had to explain these schemes and how the tea workers could benefit from them. Key Learning Overall, the study highlights the need for greater awareness and accessibility of  Government Social Protection schemes for tea garden workers in West Bengal. There is a need for robust mechanisms to be placed to ensure that all the tea garden workers receive benefits from these schemes.        7.2.a. Swaniti initiative collaborated with the Department of Post, Government of  West Bengal, and organized the Aadhaar enrollment and Correction camp in Balasun, Dhooteria, Lingia, and Gopalpur Tea Gardens. The camps aimed to reach out to as many people as possible and efficiently conduct the enrollment and correction processes. These camps successfully reached out a total of 1,309 beneficiaries, further to which Swaniti will work on linking these beneficiaries to different government schemes.   Example: A voice from the community -   Hello my name is Sujata Manger and this is my son Ankit Manger he was unable to obtain an Aadhaar card, but thanks to this camp, he was able to get it without difficulty. He is not alone, there are a number of other people in the tea garden who also do not have an Aadhaar card. I am now optimistic that my son will be able to access different government schemes after getting his Aadhaar card - Sujata Manager - Dhajea TG, Darjeeling   Outcomes of the Aadhar Correction Camps:  Oak Progress Report.    4 1. The camps were able to enroll and correct the Aadhaar details of a total of 1,309 beneficiaries. These beneficiaries were able to obtain their Aadhaar cards without any difficulty and ensure their details were updated and accurate. 2. Many tea garden workers in the vicinity, including Tumsun TE, Munda, Miling, Kalej Valley TG, and Samirkpani TE, were able to get their Aadhaar cards corrected conveniently as a result of the camps. This helped them avoid the inconvenience and expense of traveling long distances to access Aadhaar services. 3. The teams working at the camps conducted awareness sessions to educate people about the importance of Aadhaar and its benefits. This helped people understand the significance of the Aadhaar card and its role in accessing various government schemes and services. 4. The successful acquisition of Aadhaar cards by the beneficiaries will enable them to access various government schemes and services with ease. This will help them avail themselves of important benefits and support provided by the government. 5. The Aadhaar card helps the government to maintain accurate and updated data on tea garden workers, which can be used for planning and policy formulation. Overall, Swaniti's efforts to link tea garden workers with different government schemes through the correction of their Aadhaar cards will help ensure that tea garden workers have access to the available social protection schemes, thereby building a more inclusive and equitable society in West Bengal.        7.2.c. Please share a candid assessment of areas of challenge and learning and whether any adjustments were made. Challenges: Over the course of one year, a number of attempts were made through various channels in order to establish convergence and acquire the necessary permissions for conducting Aadhaar camps. These efforts were made in the face of significant opposition from various stakeholders (like private associations, local leaders, etc.) who stood to benefit from maintaining the existing status quo, rather than facilitating social and financial inclusion for the dependents of tea gardens. The opposition that the team encountered was multifaceted and ranged from vitriolic political interference sometime creating a major bottleneck in service delivery. Despite these challenges, the team was able to organize Aadhaar Enrollment/ correction camps that enabled more than 1300 dependents to become eligible for a range of social welfare schemes.  Learnings: As a learning strategy, Swaniti plans to onboard the district administrations of all four districts when organizing the Aadhaar camps and other interventions for a smooth flow of work processes. Swaniti also plans to onboard and work with the  forms of government and private ( Team associations) stakeholders to reach the maximum number of garden workers through the intervention plan in place. Swaniti is working across a  range of stakeholders ranging from the communities into the district and state administration at large. We are in the process of creating pockets of evidence that can work as proof of concepts for scale up and adoption by the key decision makers. To achieve this we have designed the following strategy : Needs assessment: A thorough needs assessment was conducted to identify the specific challenges faced by tea garden workers in accessing social protection schemes. That includes issues related to documentation, access to information, and barriers related to caste or gender. Stakeholder mapping and engagement: Tea garden workers themselves, as well as community leaders, civil society organizations, and other Government stakeholders, were mapped to be engaged in the policy development process, ensuring that the needs and perspectives of the aforementioned groups are considered. Capacity building: The policy framework includes provisions for building the capacity of tea garden workers to access and utilize social protection schemes. This includes training on documentation and application procedures, as well as outreach and awareness raising efforts to ensure that workers are aware of their rights and entitlements. Interdepartmental coordination: Coordination between different government departments and agencies being crucial for ensuring the effective implementation of social protection schemes, the policy framework works to ensure interdepartmental coordination and collaboration. Monitoring and evaluation: Regular monitoring and evaluation of the implementation of the policy framework involving regular feedback from tea garden workers and other stakeholders, as well as quantitative data on enrollment and utilization of social protection schemes. Grassroots implementation: The implementation of the policy framework ensures that tea garden workers are aware of the available schemes and their accessibility. Sanhita, in its effort to reach out to the most marginalised women workers within the organised sector, chose to engage with the women of the two most important industries in the states economy, viz, Jute & Tea. The Jute Mills in the state employs around 25000 women workers and the number is constantly increasing over the past two years. Historically, tea plantations have always been a traditional employer of large number of women. Almost 61% of the 3.2 lakh workers employed in the tea plantations of West Bengal are women. However, information on the safety of women workers (ie. sexual harassment as an aspect of working condition and welfare) is lacking in both the industries. In order to create a body of evidence which would help in advocacy for safe workspaces, Sanhita conducted Situation Analysis in both the industries to understand the safety of women workers (in the context of sexual harassment at workplace). The studies investigated the perceptions and prevalence of sexual harassment, the accountability of key stakeholders towards promoting safe workplace for women and the implementation of 2013 Act. These reports will serve as an important document on the safety of women workers in the jute mills and tea plantations. The Situation Analysis in Jute Industry was conducted in 2019 among women workers of 6 Jute Mills and leadership of 7 Jute Federations and 6 Jute Unions in Hooghly and North 24 Parganas districts. The Situation Analysis in Tea Plantations was conducted in 2022 and covered government and non-government stakeholders like the district administration, the Labour Department of GoWB, the tea garden management, trade unions, tea associations; besides the women workers themselves from 24 tea gardens in two (Dooars and Terai) of the three tea growing regions. Some of the key findings common to both industries that have emerged from the two independent studies are:  Lack of awareness regarding safe workplaces (including sexual harassment of women at workplace (SHW), the POSH Act, 2013 and its provisions) of almost all respondents in the jute mills & the tea gardens.  Compliance with the Act is marginal.  The issue of safe workplaces, in the context of sexual harassment, has not even been considered to be an integral component of working conditions or labour rights of women workers. The very large numbers of women employed in the two industries studied are vulnerable due to their position at the bottom of the hierarchy, casualisation of employment, overall isolated and dependent work conditions which are further compounded by poverty, low wages, migration status, domestic violence and low literacy levels. The government departments like the district administration (District Officer) who is responsible for overall implementation of 2013 Act in the respective districts or the labour department who is responsible for overall welfare and rights of workers have not adopted any appropriate measures towards ensuring safe workplaces for marginal women workers.  Oak Progress Report.    3 Sanhita has utilised the Situation Analysis findings as a tool for advocacy and intervention with multiple stakeholders. The outreach to women workers has been channelled through intense and consistent engagement with the Trade Unions who are directly working with them. Parallelly Sanhita conducted evidence-based advocacy with the employers, employers association, Labour Department and District Administration for creating safe workplaces for its women workers through implementation and monitoring of the 2013 Act. Overall Outcomes in both Industries  Knowledge Creation on status of safe workplaces for marginalised women workers: The 2 Situation Analysis studies have created thus far unavailable information and evidence on the safety of women workers in the jute mills and tea plantations in West Bengal.  Voices of Women Workers were documented and shared with relevant stakeholders: The hitherto unheard voices of the underrepresented women workers in the jute mills and tea plantations were brought to light by Sanhita through Situation Analysis study and the intervention programmes. The voices served as evidence for Sanhitas dialogue and advocacy with the key stakeholders like the monitoring bodies, the employers and the trade unions.    The plight of the women workers in Jute Mills and Tea Plantations get highlighted in print Media articles: During the course of dissemination of the Situation Analysis findings, Sanhita organised 2 centralised meetings with the Jute Mill Unions and Tea Plantation Unions respectively. These events and the study findings got very well covered in the media articles. Following this different groups working with marginal/unorganised workers have reached out to Sanhita seeking further information. The Situation Analysis report soft and hard copies have been widely disseminated among these different groups and organisations. Sanhita has taken multiple routes to ensure that marginal women workers gain access to the information on SHW issue, the 2013 Act and their rights to a safe workplace. One of this has been integral to the intervention process both during the course of conducting the Situation Analysis as well through sharing the findings of the report with the women workers. The other approach has been through dissemination of stakeholder specific IEC materials which provided information both on the issue and the Act.  Women Workers in the Jute Mills received information on the issue of SHW and the 2013 Act  Through a series of orientation sessions, it has been possible to directly reach out to 225 workers from around 8 Jute Mills in the Hooghly and North 24 Parganas districts. 86% of the workers i.e 194 were women. Strategically, some interested and active male workers were also included in these orientation programmes.  The programmes were organised in the Muhallas of the jute mills in Gate Meeting style.  Oak Progress Report.    6  The women workers who participated initially with trepidation have over a period of time gained the confidence to speak out about their own experiences in the workplace and instances of sexual harassment faced.  There has been a gradual swell of womens active participation in the meetings as well as within the unions.  Trade Unions collaborated with Sanhita in this initiative. They took an active role in selecting the meeting venue in the vicinity of the jute mills, ensuring participation of the women workers from the adjacent jute mills and arranging logistics for the programmes.  The meetings served as a platform for raising the awareness of the women workers on the issue, the Act and their rights as workers. This understanding of their rights is what is motivating the women to break their silence and speak out. Reaching out to Women Workers in the Tea Gardens A similar process is underway with select Tea Gardens in North Bengal wherein the findings of the Situation Analysis will be shared with the women workers in the plantations. This initiative has already been included in the Intervention Plan for 2023-2024.  Stakeholder specific IEC Material Primer on the POSH Act, 2013  A comprehensive document in English which presents the provisions and nuances of the POSH Act, 2013 in a lucid and easy to understand format. This has been extensively shared with Employers, Employers Associations, Internal Committees (ICs), NGOs & Human Rights Activists, Monitoring Bodies and the Trade Unions. The Primer is being disseminated in both soft and hard copies.  Booklet in Bangla (Karmakhetre Jouno Henosthar Mokabilay Narikarmee)  In a scenario where there was not a single material available on SHW issue and the Act in Bangla language which could be read and understood by women workers Sanhita developed and printed this booklet. It not only explains the issue and the Act in simple language but also gives practical information on what women can do during a crisis situation. The booklet has been disseminated to marginal Women Workers and Trade Unions among others. There has been a demand from the unions in North Bengal & the Jute Mills for the booklet to be provided in Hindi and the translation has already been completed and printing in progress. Leaflet in 3 languages (Say No to SHW)  Printed in English, Bangla and Hindi the leaflets provide a snapshot view of the Act viz a viz employers responsibility and womens workplace rights. This easy to comprehend content has been extensively circulated among women workers and other stakeholders. These leaflets are also available in white board animation format. Situation Analysis Reports  The Situation Analysis not only captures the voices of women workers in Jute Mills and Tea Plantations, but its findings are also being taken back to the women workers so that they gain an understanding regarding the status of safety at their own workplaces. Sanhitas footprint at the Kolkata Book Fair 2023  Sanhitas strategic partner Nagarik Manchas stall at the Kolkata Book Fair was dedicated to the issue of Marginal Women Workforce. The stall had a display of all of Sanhitas IEC materials which were widely disseminated. The issue of SHW in the context of marginal women workers got highlighted for the first time ever at a prestigious event such as the Book Fair. Crisis Intervention Services To support redress of complaints, Sanhita adopted multi-pronged strategies  support to aggrieved women, support to SHW Committees in dealing with complaints, identification of procedural and knowledge gaps in handling of SHW complaints, and understanding of barriers in effective case redress for strengthening the justice delivery mechanism in the capacity of external member, support group or advisor.  Oak Progress Report.    7   In the capacity of External Member Presently Sanhita is representing at about 14 Complaints Committees across Education Institutions, Medical Colleges & Hospitals, Central & State Government offices which employ a large number of women workers and/or working as Sanhitas strategic partners. These SHW Committees receive technical support at regular interval from Sanhita to deal with the complaints effectively. In the past one year (April, 2022  March, 2023) Sanhita has dealt with 5 complaints in the capacity of External Member in the Internal Committees (ICs) and in two cases Sanhita has played the support role. 1 case has been reported in a Security Force of Central Government, 2 cases were from a Central Government organisation and 2 cases were from 2 different Medical Colleges & Hospitals.  As a result of Sanhitas presence, facilitation and participation, the following outcomes were achieved in dealing SHW complaints in the ICs.  The procedures were followed properly, the case was conclusive and aggrieved women received justice through the Internal Committee in the Security Force of Central Government and 2 Medical Colleges and Hospitals. In one case of the central government organisation, ICs had to take Ex-parte decision due to absence of complainant in three consecutive hearings and in another case, the IC has submitted report of the preliminary inquiry to the disciplinary authority recommending the need for final inquiry as the IC has found merit in the complaint during the preliminary inquiry. As a result of Sanhitas advocacy, a central government organisation employing a large number of women has launched its online complaint format on SHW.   In the capacity of Support Group and Advisor In the past one year, Sanhita also provided the technical support to the Presiding Officers, Members and External Members. On 10th February, 2023, Sanhita conducted a centralised training for the ICs from 9 government department/organisations, 19 non-government organisations and 8 private organisations through centralised training. In these committees, Sanhita does not represent as external members. As a result of Sanhitas role as a support group and advisor, the following outcomes could be achieved. In two complaints from two different eminent Universities, Sanhita provided legal advice and counselling support to the aggrieved persons who approached the organisation directly. A group of engineering students (both female & male) lodged a mass complaint against one of the faculty members to the IC of their university. The complainants also approached media houses. Sanhita assisted the senior journalists from a renowned media house who reached out to Sanhita in order to understand the ethics and strategy of reporting the mass complaint on SHW.    7.2.c. Please share a candid assessment of areas of challenge and learning and whether any adjustments were made. Reaching out to women workers The employers are reluctant to give access to the casual, unorganised and marginal workers within their organisations. When it comes to ensuring safe workplaces for women employees, the  Oak Progress Report.    8 employers accountability extends to only women working in offices. Though the industries are dependent on the women workers in their factories, mills and plantations these women dont exist in their policies and there is no eagerness to change the status quo of this invisibility. The only way for Sanhita to access the women workers is through strategic partnerships with trade unions working with them or with NGO which are either directly working with them or working with the communities that they are part of. It has been rather challenging to raise the issue of sexual harassment in such public forum which is a first of its kind experience for the mill workers. Working with the Unions The unions being patriarchal structures are not too keen to work with feminist/womens groups. They are also weary of NGOs in general and are skeptical about what results a collaboration can yield. Sanhitas strategic partnership with Nagarik Mancha and its persistent endeavours helped in not only breaking the ice with the unions but also bringing different unions together on a common platform. Working closely with the unions, Sanhita was able to reach the women workers.   Crisis Intervention Experiences of Complainants Almost all complainants have been experiencing Character assassination, humiliation and hostile work environment irrespective of their designation, employment status & work sector. Sanhita experiences the following concern areas in dealing SHW complaints as a support group & advisor: Challenges in following Inquiry Procedure  In most of the cases, Sanhita experienced lack of technical knowhow about inquiry procedure among IC members. ICs where Sanhita is not the External member were also unaware about the SHW issue. Knowledge Gap among Aggrieved Sanhita noted a knowledge gap among students who approached Sanhita for legal advice and counseling support. The engineering students were definitely empowered, but, were found to be lacking even in basic information about their rights laid down in the 2013 Act. They also did not have any understanding about how to deal with such harassment.  ICs not Equipped In two complaints, where Sanhita has played a support role, the ICs were not equipped enough to handle the complaints. Sanhita identified the gaps in Technical knowledge, like process of inquiry, service  rules of the organization, legal aspects etc and also found lacunae in documentation process. As a result of this, the aggrieved faced hostility from their ICs. Non-cooperative Authority /Administration Aggrieved also faced non-cooperation from the Authority/Administration in both the education institutes.    7.3.a. Changemakers Program in Assam: The Changemakers Program was launched in Assam in April 2022 by Nazdeeks grantee partner, PAJHRA. The purpose was to support 14 Adivasi youth to build knowledge and capacity towards holistic leadership skills. They were provided 6 in-person residential trainings, 2.5 days long each, covering sessions on (1) culture, history and society, (2) civic education, and (3) skills such as research, writing and reporting. Each training was followed by supervised field work in communities, wherein the participants conducted Focus Group Discussions, Individual structured interviews and submitted 4 reports per participant in the duration of the Program. Each of the reports were a part of their homework, which involved field work on a selected issue (such as the Public Distribution System or Anganwadi) and then preparing a report to document the activity and analyse the results. To culminate the program, 08 of the fellows were taken on an Exposure Visit where they visited historical monuments and interacted with organisations such as DISHA, Durbar, and Jana Sanghati Kendra. The idea behind the visit was to provide a chance to these Adivasi youths hailing from remote plantations and with limited opportunities for travel and urban exposure to learn about metropolitan lifestyles, Indian art and history, and to gain a wider understanding of socio-economic issues and CSO based interventions outside the plantations space and with demographies other than Adivasis. Of the 14 participants, 09 were women and 05 were men; most hailing from a social work and legal education background. The syllabus, pedagogy, design and monitoring, and selection process was developed under the guidance of subject matter experts such as Prof. Virginius Xaxa. For each session, training modules (15 in total) were created. In terms of the progress in achieving Objective 1, as the first in a three-year process, this Program was successful. Based on the skills mapping and expectation analysis conducted with the cohort, it is evident that they increased, and in certain subjects acquired first time knowledge, on matters of Indian governance structure, entitlements on health, food, labour, grievance redressal systems, information applications, issues-stakeholder-risk analysis, desk and field research and writing. Significantly, as is also reflected in the Most Significant Change stories attached herewith, they developed and strengthened critical thinking, public speaking, networking and outreach skills and grew demonstrably in confidence and self-respect. Motivated by the learnings, participants from the program have gone on to work as Accredited Social Healthcare Activists in tea plantations, gender committee President of tea worker womens collectives, while some are conducting independent research on Deposit Linked Insurance Scheme for tea workers, have enrolled in graduate level Labour Economic courses, and have become more active as members of workers collectives. In various feedback sessions, the participants have shown a keenness to work within their community and on issues concerning tea workers at large in their professional or individual capacity, as feasible. Promotion of Pulses, Oilseeds and Vegetables During the Kharif season, 619 farmers received vegetable seed (cabbage, pumpkin, okra, horse gram, tomato etc.) support as part of promoting vegetables amongst the tribal farmersSimilarly, during the Rabi season, 26 farmers received mustard seeds of 1 kg on an average out of which the total mustard seed production was 597 kgs. Further, 59 farmers received support to promote kitchen garden. The farmers use high yielding variety of seeds in paddy and indigenous seeds for other crops. The shift to natural farming is a gradual process and so the gradation of change process is followed in CPF. In the initial phase, with few agro-ecological practices are promoted. Farmers are trained and encouraged to apply organic fertilizers (Ghanjeevamritam and Jeevamritam) and organic pesticides (Neemastram and Agniastram). The farmers treat the seeds before sowing by following the process of Beejamritam. Capacitating Maintenance of Watershed Structures Though the area receives good rainfall, the water is not being retained as the watershed structures constructed by government are not functional. So, the farmers are being given trainings on the maintenance of watershed structures. 13 watershed structures were identified for repair and maintenance. 1 water tank was desilted in Parashiya village (Barikul GP) with the project cost of Rs.1.38 lakh and farmers contribution were Rs. 12,000. Around, 180 farmers did Shramdan for 5 days. CPFs intervention had a ripple effect and the communities desilted another tank on their own. Further, they also repaired a check dam by contributing Rs.12000/-. Soil Test To introduce the scientific method of understanding the soil, the farmers were trained on undertaking soil tests. Soil samples were sent for testing to KVK Sonamukhi, Bankura. In the first batch, soil samples of 121 farmers were sent and the result indicated that most of the soil contains high acidic content. The results and recommendations are shared with the farmers to improve the soil health. For instance, if the NPK (Nitrogen, Phosphorous and Potassium) content is low, the farmers are advised to increase the NPK by applying vermicompost, farm yard manure and green manure.  Another batch of 107 Soil samples have been collected from the farmers and sent for testing. The results are yet to come.
One Year Progress Report - UPDATED VERSI.Project Objective 3: Enhancing access to: .As majority of the communities (70%) are dependent upon Non-Timber Forest Produces (NTFPs) for additional incomes, it is imperative that the communities are made aware about the importance of forest and their conservation. Towards this end, CPF has conducted 5 trainings on sustainable harvesting of NTFPs and value addition. Local experts and forest department officials were involved as resource persons to provide awareness to the NTFP collectors of our project villages. NTFP collectors were informed about the negative impacts of over harvesting of NTFPs and the need for value addition (leaf plate making, pickles etc.) to fetch more incomes. As far as marketing of the NTFPs are concerned, the project staff has explored different options by speaking and consulting number of persons/organizations such as the DFO of Bankura South Division, Ranibandh Range Officer, PRADAN, traders and NTFP collectors themselves. Two of our community field facilitators (CFFs) were trained on leaflet making and are aware of markets linkages. So, CPF is exploring to reestablish the market linkages through them and Self-Help Groups (SHGs) in each GP under Ranibandh Block for the marketing of NTFPs. As suggested, TRIFED option also will be explored. To enhance the income of landless, resource poor and single headed households, backyard poultry farming has been promoted. 42 community members from Ranibandh and Barikul were provided with poultry of local breed (3 each). Awareness meetings on Forest Rights Act (FRA-2006) are being conducted at the village level to make them aware about the Community Forest Rights (CFR) and the claim process. CPF has built rapport and collaborated with the Forest Department in plantation and value addition of NTFPs. The SDLC through Block Land Records Office (BLRO)/BDO has distributed IFR titles few years ago but in our operational areas no CFR titles have been submitted. The West Bengal Tribal Development Portal mentions that in Bankura district 210 CFRs have been distributed (https://adibasikalyan.gov.in/forest-right-act ) and we are trying to know where these titles are given. In the next year, we are planning to submit CFR claims in our villages after the formation of Forest Rights Committees (FRCs).

ChallengesIn West Bengal, the government officials are not accepting filing of petitions on a regular basis for social security programs and entitlements and they are only accepting during the Duare Sarkar camps and they are also not being held regularly.  We have approached the Right to Food and Work Network (RTFWN) and planning to meet them at the earliest. In Sandeshkhali area, the bureaucratic hurdles in getting permission to operate in villages has taken considerable time and energy. However, now in all the 12 villages, we got permission to operate.    It took some time to ground the project but with persons having agriculture qualifications and experience has helped in grounding the project at faster pace.
